update.description:
This is a general purpose class that follows [this formula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ornstein%E2%80%93Uhlenbeck_process).

I chose to call it a GaussMarkov process insteas of an OrnsteinUhlenbeck because of name recognition and ease of typing.

I plan to use this for modeling sea currents.
update.title: Added GaussMarkovProcess

content.raw: I made a couple of minor comments and suggested improvements to the tests. After those are addressed, lgtm.
content.html: I made a couple of minor comments and suggested improvements to the tests. After those are addressed, lgtm.

content.raw: This test will have the same reliability issue as the C\+\+ version. But I lack the ruby skills to fix it :\)
content.html: This test will have the same reliability issue as the C++ version. But I lack the ruby skills to fix it :)

content.raw:
I don’t think that this test will reliably pass. It only took me two tries to get it to fail:

```
$ ./bin/UNIT_GaussMarkovProcess_TEST
Running main() from gtest_main.cc
[==========] Running 3 tests from 1 test case.
[----------] Global test environment set-up.
[----------] 3 tests from GaussMarkovProcessTest
[ RUN      ] GaussMarkovProcessTest.DefaultConstructor
[       OK ] GaussMarkovProcessTest.DefaultConstructor (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] GaussMarkovProcessTest.Update
[       OK ] GaussMarkovProcessTest.Update (1 ms)
[ RUN      ] GaussMarkovProcessTest.Noise
/home/gerkey/code/rse/ign/ign-math/src/GaussMarkovProcess_TEST.cc:91: Failure
Expected: (value) > (-10), actual: -10.5258 vs -10
/home/gerkey/code/rse/ign/ign-math/src/GaussMarkovProcess_TEST.cc:91: Failure
Expected: (value) > (-10), actual: -10.2249 vs -10
/home/gerkey/code/rse/ign/ign-math/src/GaussMarkovProcess_TEST.cc:91: Failure
Expected: (value) > (-10), actual: -10.6587 vs -10
/home/gerkey/code/rse/ign/ign-math/src/GaussMarkovProcess_TEST.cc:91: Failure
Expected: (value) > (-10), actual: -10.5162 vs -10
[  FAILED  ] GaussMarkovProcessTest.Noise (0 ms)
[----------] 3 tests from GaussMarkovProcessTest (1 ms total)

[----------] Global test environment tear-down
[==========] 3 tests from 1 test case ran. (1 ms total)
[  PASSED  ] 2 tests.
[  FAILED  ] 1 test, listed below:
[  FAILED  ] GaussMarkovProcessTest.Noise

 1 FAILED TEST
```

You could widen the acceptance band to make it fail less often, but eventually you’ll get an unlikely sample that violates any threshold that you pick. I’ll suggest an alternative in a PR.

You could widen the acceptance band to make it fail less often, but eventually you’ll get an unlikely sample that violates any threshold that you pick. I’ll suggest an alternative in a PR.

content.raw: Same comment as for line 35 above.
Is this line commented out as a reminder to add a LastUpdate\(\) method in the future, or is it leftover copy-and-paste from elsewhere? If the latter, I’d remove it.
content.html: Is this line commented out as a reminder to add a LastUpdate() method in the future, or is it leftover copy-and-paste from elsewhere? If the latter, I’d remove it.

content.raw: It may be worth mentioning that you’re implementing the variation with a drift param, which is apparently called the Vasicek model \([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasicek\_model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasicek_model)\).
content.html: It may be worth mentioning that you’re implementing the variation with a drift param, which is apparently called the Vasicek model (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasicek_model).

update.description:
This is a general purpose class that follows [this formula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ornstein%E2%80%93Uhlenbeck_process).

I chose to call it a GaussMarkov process insteas of an OrnsteinUhlenbeck because of name recognition and ease of typing.

I plan to use this for modeling sea currents.
update.title: Added GaussMarkovProcess

content.raw: I don’t know that the norm is in this library. Should we warn when clamping the input params to reasonable values?
content.html: I don’t know that the norm is in this library. Should we warn when clamping the input params to reasonable values?
